article.title: The Resonant Drag Instability (RDI): Acoustic Modes

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the linear growth rates of the acoustic resonant drag instability (RDI) for dust moving through gas. Which of the following statements about the growth rate (ω) is **incorrect**?
choices: For subsonic cases (˜ws < 1), the growth rate saturates at a maximum value and modes are stabilized at high wavenumbers (k).
For supersonic cases (˜ws ≥ 1), the growth rate increases indefinitely with wavenumber at the resonant angle (cosθ = ±1/˜ws).
The growth rate is always higher for larger dust-to-gas mass ratios (µ).
The growth rate is expressed in units of the equilibrium dust drag timescale or "stopping time" (ts).

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 illustrates the spatial structure of different modes of the acoustic RDI. Which mode exhibits a nearly-coherent dust-gas oscillation with a phase offset and diverging phase/group velocities as k → 0?

Figure 3 compares growth rates for different drag laws.  Which drag law, in the supersonic regime (˜ws  1), generally shows stabilized quasi-sound modes at high wavenumbers due to the stronger coupling from high relative velocity?
Figure 4 shows the influence of varying dust-to-gas ratios (µ) on the growth rates. Which statement about the dependence of growth rate on µ is **correct**?
choices: For subsonic cases (˜ws < 1), the maximum growth rate (marginalizing over k) increases proportionally to µ.
For supersonic cases (˜ws > 1), the growth rates are entirely independent of µ.
At large µ  1, the low and intermediate-k growth rates become independent of µ.
For all cases, the high-k growth rate increases proportionally to µ.
